title.rendered: What is R?

content.rendered: R is an interpreted computer programming language which was created by Ross Ihaka and Robert Gentleman at the University of Auckland, New Zealand”. It is a software environment used to analyze statistical information, graphical representation, reporting, and data modeling. R is the implementation of the S programming language, which is combined with lexical scoping semantics.

excerpt.rendered: R is an interpreted computer programming language which was created by Ross Ihaka and Robert Gentleman at the University of Auckland, New Zealand”. It is a software environment used to analyze statistical information, graphical representation, reporting, and data modeling. R is the implementation of the S programming language, which is combined with lexical scoping semantics.

title.rendered: Differentiate between vector, List, Matrix, and Data frame.

content.rendered:
A vector is a series of data elements of the same basic type. The members in the vector are known as a component.

The R object that contains elements of different types such as numbers, strings, vectors, or another list inside it, is known as List.

A two-dimensional data structure used to bind the vectors from the same length, known as the matrix. The matrix contains the same types of elements.

A Data frame is a generic form of a matrix. It is a combination of lists and matrices. In the Data frame, different data columns contain different data types.

excerpt.rendered: A vector is a series of data elements of the same basic type. The members in the vector are known as a component. The R object that contains elements of different types such as numbers, strings, vectors, or another list inside it, is known as List. A two-dimensional data structure used to bind the vectors from the same […]

title.rendered: Give names of those packages which are used for data imputation.

content.rendered:
There are the following packages which are used for data imputation

  1. MICE
  2. missFores
  3. Mi
  4. Hmisc
  5. Amelia
  6. imputeR

excerpt.rendered: There are the following packages which are used for data imputation MICE missFores Mi Hmisc Amelia imputeR

title.rendered: Explain initialize() function in R?

content.rendered: This function is used to initialize the private data members while declaring the object

excerpt.rendered: This function is used to initialize the private data members while declaring the object

title.rendered: How can we find the mean of one column with respect to another?

content.rendered:
In iris dataset, there are five columns, i.e., Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, Petal.Length, Petal.Width and Species. We will calculate the mean of Sepal-Length across different species of iris flower using the mean() function from the mosaic package.

  1. mean(iris$Sepal.Length~iris$Species)

excerpt.rendered: In iris dataset, there are five columns, i.e., Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, Petal.Length, Petal.Width and Species. We will calculate the mean of Sepal-Length across different species of iris flower using the mean() function from the mosaic package. mean(iris$Sepal.Length~iris$Species)

title.rendered: Give any five features of R.

content.rendered:
1. Simple and effective programming language.
  2. It is a data analysis software.
  3. It gives effective storage facility and data handling.
  4. It gives high extensible graphical techniques.
  5. It is an interpreted language.

excerpt.rendered: Simple and effective programming language. It is a data analysis software. It gives effective storage facility and data handling. It gives high extensible graphical techniques. It is an interpreted language.

title.rendered: Differentiate between R and Python in terms of functionality?

content.rendered: For data analysis, R has inbuilt functionality, but in Python, the data analysis functionalities are not inbuilt. They are available by packages like Pandas and Numpy.

excerpt.rendered: For data analysis, R has inbuilt functionality, but in Python, the data analysis functionalities are not inbuilt. They are available by packages like Pandas and Numpy.

title.rendered: What are the applications of R?

content.rendered:
There are various applications available in real-time. These applications are as follows:

  1. Facebook
  2. Google
  3. Twitter
  4. HRDAG
  5. NDAA

excerpt.rendered: There are various applications available in real-time. These applications are as follows: Facebook Google Twitter HRDAG NDAA

title.rendered: Explain RStudio.

content.rendered: RStudio is an integrated development environment which allows us to interact with R more readily. RStudio is similar to the standard RGui, but it is considered more user-friendly. This IDE has various drop-down menus, windows with multiple tabs, and so many customization processes. The first time when we open RStudio, we will see three Windows. The fourth Window will be hidden by default.

excerpt.rendered: RStudio is an integrated development environment which allows us to interact with R more readily. RStudio is similar to the standard RGui, but it is considered more user-friendly. This IDE has various drop-down menus, windows with multiple tabs, and so many customization processes. The first time when we open RStudio, we will see three Windows. […]

title.rendered: What are the advantages and disadvantages of R?

content.rendered:
Advantages

  1. Open Source
  2. Data Wrangling
  3. Array of Packages
  4. Platform Independent
  5. Machine Learning Operations

Disadvantages

  1. Weak origin
  2. Data Handling
  3. Basic Security
  4. Complicated Language
  5. Lesser Speed

excerpt.rendered: Advantages Open Source Data Wrangling Array of Packages Platform Independent Machine Learning Operations Disadvantages Weak origin Data Handling Basic Security Complicated Language Lesser Speed

title.rendered: What is the purpose behind R and Hadoop integration?

content.rendered:
1. For executing Hadoop to execute R code.
  2. For using R to access the data stored in Hadoop.

excerpt.rendered: For executing Hadoop to execute R code. For using R to access the data stored in Hadoop.

content.rendered:
1. R Hadoop
  2. Hadoop Streaming
  3. RHIPE
  4. ORCH

What is the difference b/w sample() and subset() in R?

content.rendered: The sample() method is used to choose a random sample of size n from a dataset while the subset method is used to choose variables and observations.

excerpt.rendered: The sample() method is used to choose a random sample of size n from a dataset while the subset method is used to choose variables and observations.

title.rendered: Why do we use the command – install.packages(file.choose(), repos=NULL)?

content.rendered: This command is used to install an R package from the local directory by browsing and selecting the file.

excerpt.rendered: This command is used to install an R package from the local directory by browsing and selecting the file.

title.rendered: Give the command to create a histogram and to remove a vector from the R workspace?

content.rendered: hist() and rm() function are used as a command to create a histogram and remove a vector from the R workspace.

excerpt.rendered: hist() and rm() function are used as a command to create a histogram and remove a vector from the R workspace.

content.rendered: The “%%” provides a reminder of the division of the first vector with the second, and the “%/%” gives the quotient of the division of the first vector with the second.

excerpt.rendered: The “%%” provides a reminder of the division of the first vector with the second, and the “%/%” gives the quotient of the division of the first vector with the second.

title.rendered: Why do we use apply() function in R?

content.rendered: This is used to apply the same function to each of the elements in an Array. For example, finding the mean of the rows in every row.

excerpt.rendered: This is used to apply the same function to each of the elements in an Array. For example, finding the mean of the rows in every row.

title.rendered: Differentiate between library() and require() functions.

content.rendered: If the desired package cannot be loaded, then the library() function gives an error message and display while the required () function is used inside the function and throws a warning message whenever a particular package is not found.

excerpt.rendered: If the desired package cannot be loaded, then the library() function gives an error message and display while the required () function is used inside the function and throws a warning message whenever a particular package is not found.

title.rendered: What is the t-test() in R?

content.rendered: The t-test() function is used to determine that the mean of the two groups are equal or not.

excerpt.rendered: The t-test() function is used to determine that the mean of the two groups are equal or not.

title.rendered: What is the use of with() and by() functions in R?

content.rendered: The with() function applies an expression to a dataset, and the by() function applies a function to each level of factors.

excerpt.rendered: The with() function applies an expression to a dataset, and the by() function applies a function to each level of factors.

title.rendered: Differentiate b/w lapply and sapply.

content.rendered: The lapply is used to show the output in the form of the list, whereas sapply is used to show the output in the form of a vector or data frame.

excerpt.rendered: The lapply is used to show the output in the form of the list, whereas sapply is used to show the output in the form of a vector or data frame.

title.rendered: Explain aggregate() function.

content.rendered: The aggregate() function is used to aggregate data in R. There are two methods which are collapsing data by using one or more BY variable and other is an aggregate() function in which By variable should be in the list.

excerpt.rendered: The aggregate() function is used to aggregate data in R. There are two methods which are collapsing data by using one or more BY variable and other is an aggregate() function in which By variable should be in the list.

title.rendered: Explain the doBy package?

content.rendered: This package is used to define the desired table using function and model formula.

excerpt.rendered: This package is used to define the desired table using function and model formula.

title.rendered: Explain the use of the table() function.

content.rendered: This function is used to create the frequency table in R.

excerpt.rendered: This function is used to create the frequency table in R.

title.rendered: Explain fitdistr() function?

content.rendered: This function is used to give the maximum likelihood fitting of univariate distribution and defined under the MASS package.

excerpt.rendered: This function is used to give the maximum likelihood fitting of univariate distribution and defined under the MASS package.

title.rendered: What are GGobi and iPlots?

content.rendered: The GGobi is an open-source program for visualization to exploring high dimensional typed data, and the iPlots is a package which provides bar plots, mosaic plots, box plots, parallel plots, histograms, and scatter plots.

excerpt.rendered: The GGobi is an open-source program for visualization to exploring high dimensional typed data, and the iPlots is a package which provides bar plots, mosaic plots, box plots, parallel plots, histograms, and scatter plots.

title.rendered: Explain the lattice package.

content.rendered: The lattice package is meant to improve upon the base R graphics by giving better defaults and has the ability to display multivariate relationships easily.

excerpt.rendered: The lattice package is meant to improve upon the base R graphics by giving better defaults and has the ability to display multivariate relationships easily.
